She was born in New Zealand and studied at the Royal College of Music in London. She made her professional debut in 1953 and went on to perform in the world's leading opera houses, including the Metropolitan Opera in New York. She was renowned for her powerful and expressive voice, and was particularly celebrated for her performances of Puccini's Tosca and Verdi's Aida. She was also a champion of contemporary music, performing works by composers such as Benjamin Britten and Michael Tippett. She was awarded a Dame Commander of the British Empire in 1982 and was made a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit in 2008.
